title: Rental scams (pay bond/rent before inspection; fake bond emails)
summary: Rental scammers advertise properties they don’t own and pressure you to pay bond/rent quickly—sometimes using fake ‘bond confirmation’ emails.
how_it_works: A rental listing looks perfect and the ‘landlord’ is very pushy.
They won’t allow inspection and ask for bond/rent upfront.
Some scams use fake emails to ‘confirm’ bond lodgement to keep you paying.
warning_signs: Excuses for why you can’t inspect the property.
Requests for bond/rent before viewing/signing properly.
Emails that imitate government/consumer protection agencies.
example_hooks: “Pay the bond today to secure it—many applicants.”
what_to_do: Never pay before inspecting and verifying the property/agent.
Verify communications come from official domains/contacts.
If you paid, contact your bank immediately and report.

quick_quiz.q: What’s the safest way to get to the real website?
choices: Click the link in the message
Type the website address yourself or use the official app
Reply and ask them for another link
quick_quiz.explain: Scam messages often include links to fake sites. Typing the address yourself (or using the official app) reduces that risk.

quick_quiz.q: A message says you must act 'within 24 hours' or you'll lose access. What should you do first?
choices: Stop and verify using official contact details you find yourself
Forward it to friends to ask
quick_quiz.explain: Urgency is a classic pressure tactic. Verify using trusted contact details.
